preface.title: Overview
preface.para: This part of the xTuple Developer Guide describes the tools you need and the steps you must follow to create a software environment to contribute to the open source xTuple software projects:

listitem.para: xTuple ERP core, including xtlib for underlying business logic and the xTuple ERP GUI

preface.para: It assumes that you have a software development background, are familiar with the operating system you will be working on, are comfortable downloading software and source code bundles from the Web, and have worked with tools similar to those described below. This chapter does not describe the only way to do things, just those we have tried with success.

It covers specific steps and details required to create a C++ development environment. People who simply want to create xTuple ERP application scripts and scripted packages, or people who want to write reports, can skip the next few chapters.

tip.para: Read the chapter for your build environment in its entirety before attempting this process.

preface.para: The following tools all have to be present to successfully create a binary version of the xTuple ERP application.

listitem.para: The source code management tool xTuple uses for version control.

The particular development tools that xTuple uses or recommends are described below. In general, however, the development environment must include a C++ compiler and an application build tool similar to make.
This is the Graphical User Interface toolkit used to build the xTuple ERP, and OpenRPT applications. Qt is available with a free LGPL license.
PostgreSQL is an open-source database engine at the heart of the xTuple ERP applications. Most of the logic of the application is written in PL/pgSQL, the PostgreSQL stored procedure language.
Another source code management tool used by some of our development partners.

preface.para: You might also want the following tools, depending on what your role is in the development effort:

listitem.para: Squish is a GUI testing tool. You'll need a license to use it. You'll also need to check out the xtupleqa sources using SVN. See http://www.froglogic.com for more information.

xTuple uses the XMLMind XML Editor (XXE) for editing documentation. There both personal and professional editions. You'll also need to check out the xtupledocs sources using SVN. Most of the documentation for xTuple ERP is written in DocBook. See http://xmlmind.com/ for more information.

cURL is a library and command line file transfer utility. The xTuple ERP application may be run with an option that uses cURL instead of Qt's networking classes when processing credit card transactions. You should not need to build cURL, as this is only needed in special circumstances when running xTuple ERP. See http://www.haxx.se/curl/ for more information.
Download two files for Windows from the cURL website: curl-version-win32-ssl.zip and libcurl-version-ssl-sspi-sspi.zip. Extract the contents of these two files to c:\curl.
cURL is pre-installed on most Macs.
Most versions of Linux have cURL packages. For example, on Ubuntu you can type sudo apt-get install curl to install it if you don't already have it.
